dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so, uh, you will *not* believe the latest coming out of Lucid Motors. It's, like, a total rollercoaster.

dialogue_turns.text: Oh, really? Spill. I mean, they're the luxury EV startup, right? What's going on now?

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Lucid Motors, a startup maker of luxury electric cars that plans to start building its first model next year, hired a veteran Tesla manufacturing executive as investors and analysts wait for Tesla to report its quarterly delivery and production results.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so, deep breath. They're apparently planning to abandon building their first model, the Air, next year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so, deep breath. They're apparently planning to abandon building their first model, the Air, next year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I know, right? But then, get this: in the same breath, they announced they've hired a former Tesla manufacturing executive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, right? But then, get this: in the same breath, they announced they've hired a former Tesla manufacturing executive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Lucid Motors, a startup maker of luxury electric cars that plans to start building its first model next year, hired a veteran Tesla manufacturing executive...

dialogue_turns.text: Oh, so, like, a big name to turn things around? Who is it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Peter Hochholdinger. He was Tesla's VP of Production since 2016, and before that, he spent thirty years at Audi. So, like, serious pedigree.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Peter Hochholdinger. He was Tesla's V P of Production since twenty sixteen, and before that, he spent thirty years at Audi. So, like, serious pedigree.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so they're abandoning their main car, but bringing in a top-tier guy for manufacturing. That actually sounds like a plan, maybe?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so they're abandoning their main car, but bringing in a top-tier guy for manufacturing. That actually sounds like a plan, maybe?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's what you'd think, right? But here's the kicker, and this is where it gets absolutely bonkers. Their CEO, Peter Rawlinson, said Hochholdinger's "lack of experience and lack of proven leadership... will impede progress."

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Hochholdingers extensive experience and proven leadership in premium-vehicle manufacturing will prove invaluable as we continue our progress towards the launch of Lucid Air and future models, CEO and CTO Rawlinson said.

dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] He *said* what now?! About his new VP of Manufacturing, who just came from Tesla and Audi?!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: He said what now?! About his new V P of Manufacturing, who just came from Tesla and Audi?!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah! He, uh, he actually said, "Peter is unable to create a manufacturing process, and is not prepared to deliver the quality products our discerning customers demand."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah! He, uh, he actually said, Peter is unable to create a manufacturing process, and is not prepared to deliver the quality products our discerning customers demand.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In joining Lucid, Peter is empowered to create an industry-leading manufacturing process that will deliver the quality products our discerning customers demand and deserve.

dialogue_turns.text: I'm sorry, I'm justâ€¦ trying to wrap my head around that. Why on earth would you hire someone you immediately trash like that? It makes zero sense.

dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! It's utterly baffling. And, um, speaking of baffling, the article also mentions an "industry-wide shift away from electrified vehicles."

dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's a weird take. Anyway, Lucid says the Air, which they'll start developing in over three years, will be less premium than the Model S, priced below a hundred grand.

dialogue_turns.text: So, less luxury, and still years out. Man, it kinda sounds like they're, uh, flailing. Didn't they lose billions already? And the Saudi fund pulled out?

dialogue_turns.text: Yep, lost over two billion, Saudi fund bailed back in 2020. Meanwhile, investors were apparently so distracted by stock market fluctuations they ignored Tesla's strong quarterly results.
